page.title: 13THE SPEECH OF PETROCKSTOWE
page.content: Many accents are heard, from BBC Eng- lish through 'Brum and Geordie to Cockney, but{Devonian predominates.}To the outsider it is odd to hear a mare or bitch called "ee" or a man referred to as "'er". Most farm stock sounds male: female cattle are only called cows if in calf or giving milk; and no-one refers to a sow although I've seen a lot of piglets! 'We will' is always 'us'll'. Normal conversation is lazy, with letters omitted. Any time past is 'backalong', and outsiders, including those from Exeter, are from "up Country". Of course the Devonian is able to "talk proper", but if 3 or 4 get together, & get enthusiastic or cross, or have taken of the farm cider the outsider can easily get lost. Devonians turn the accent on quite de- liberately to fool the foreigners, & I as one, hope they continue to do so.
